item.description: I’ve seen a lot of people use pre-made agentic frameworks to handle various tasks but I wanted to create a framework from scratch to see the brain, actions, and tools behind these agents.

item.title: Tesla's Robotaxi > Google's Waymo: Vision vs. LiDAR
item.description: In the coming years, I believe Robotaxi will scale like Uber, while Waymo will scale like Lyft - if at all. This reflects a broader paradigm shift: lean vision neural networks vs. bulky, sensor-heavy autonomy.

item.title: Deploying a toy ML model to production
item.description: I’ve trained hundreds of models in school and on my own, but barely any of them were served or pushed to production - I wanted to document what usually happens after training.

item.description: AlphaGo blew my mind and AlphaGoZero was the cherry on top. Recreating this in a simple environment was a long term dream of mine.

item.title: Can a EMNIST model run on an Amazon Kindle from 2012?
item.description: What happens when you take a modern ML model, quantize it like crazy, and try to deploy it on decade-old hardware (a potato)? I tested EMNIST on the edge — literally.

item.title: Building Transformers from scratch: Multi-Head Attention, LayerNorm, and the brain behind ChatGPT
item.description: I felt like I would never understand how LLMs really generate text until I actually create a transformer from scratch and actually code up multi-head self attention with non-modular, functional-style PyTorch.

item.title: How did we get to Transformers? The rise of Attention
item.description: Attention is really useful but just like any great invention, it was built out of necessity for the problems at hand. In this post, I aim to dive into the issues researchers were dealing with between 2013-2017.

item.title: Word2Vec from scratch: Intuition to Implementation
item.description: Q(king) - Q(man) + Q(woman) ≈ Q(queen) is beautiful but the approach we take to get there is even cooler. I wanted to dive into how these emergent properties come to be and the bottlenecks we face.

item.title: Tooling
item.description:
After a lot of trial, error, and late-night debugging, these are the tools, libraries, and frameworks I’ve come to rely on.

Development Environment

Machine I use a MacBook Pro 16” (M4, 64GB Unified Memory, 512GB SSD). When getting a laptop, I wanted a machine that could train some models locally if needed and have enough compute to play around with open source models on the laptop itself. I love the 64GB because it lets me run a training loop + Cursor + FastAPI + Docker + a bunch of browser tabs without my machine slowing down at all.
